RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduaзгo em Medicina pela Universidade Federal de Pernambuco (1971), mestrado em Ciкncias Biolуgicas (Biofнsica) pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (1975) e doutorado em Medicina Humana - Georg-August Universitat Gottingen/Alemanha (1981). Realizou estбgios pуs-doutorais (1)no Max-Planck Institute for Chemical Biophysics, em Gцttingen/Alemanha (1988-89), (2)no Kyushu Institute of Technology, no Japгo (2000), (3) no Department of Clinical Neurophysiology, Faculty of Medicine of the University of Gцttingen (em 2005) e (4) no Department of Pharmacology, University of Oxford, UK (Agosto-Novembro de 2015). Desde 1993 й professor titular da Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, mediante aprovaзгo em concurso pъblico de tнtulos e provas com defesa de tese experimental. Foi Presidente Nacional da Sociedade Brasileira de Neurociкncias e Comportamento (SBNeC), no perнodo 1999-2002. Foi eleito Membro Titular da Academia Pernambucana de Ciкncias em 2003. Й professor permanente dos Programas de PG em Nutriзгo e em Bioquнmica e Fisiologia, ambos da UFPE. Й Editor Associado das 3 seguintes revistas: 1) "Nutritional Neuroscience" (USA), 2) "Frontiers in Aging Neuroscience" (Switzerland) e 3) Brain Sciences (Manchester-UK), nas trкs com a prerrogativa de conduzir o processo editorial (indicando revisores) e ao final decidir pela aceitaзгo ou rejeiзгo dos manuscritos. Tem experiкncia na бrea de Fisiologia e Nutriзгo, com concentraзгo em Neurofisiologia, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: (1)Neurofisiologia, (2)Desnutriзгo e desenvolvimento fisiolуgico, (3)Depressгo alastrante cortical, (4)Nutriзгo e neurotransmissores; (5)Neurofarmacologia e Nutriзгo. Tornou-se professor aposentado da UFPE em abril de 2022.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Graduate in Medicine at Universidade Federal de Pernambuco (1971), Master's in Byophysics at Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (1975) and Ph.D. in Human Medicine at The Georg-August Universitat Gottingen (1981). Post-doctoral stays at the MaxPlanck Institute for Chemical Biophysics in Gцttingen/Germany (1988-89), at the Kyushu Institute for Technology/Japan (2000), at the Department of Clinical Neurophysiology, Medical School of the University of Gцttingen (2005) and at the Department of Pharmacology, University of Oxford, UK (August-November 2015). Since 1993 He is Full Professor for Neurophysiology and Nutrition at the Universidade Federal de Pernambuco. Since 2003 He is permanent member of the Academy of Sciences of the Pernambuco State, Brazil. He is permanent professor in the MS. and PhD Programs for Nutrition and Biochemistry & Physiology, both from UFPE. He serves as Associate Editor of the three following scientific journals: 1) "Nutritional Neuroscience" (USA), 2) "Frontiers in Aging Neuroscience" (Switzerland) and 3) Brain Sciences (Manchester-UK). He has experience in Physiology, focusing on Neurophysiology and acting on the following subjects: (1)Neurophysiology, (2)Nutrition and physiological development, (3)Cortical spreading depression, (4)Nutrition and neurotransmiters (5) Neuropharmacology and Nutrition.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Descriзгo: Chamada MCTI/CT - AGRONEGУCIO/CNPq Nє 39/2013. O projeto objetiva estabelecer uma estratйgia de aзхes integradas em tecnologia e inovaзгo, envolvendo o desenvolvimento e a avaliaзгo de alimentos lбcteos de caprinos do Semiбrido brasileiro, com кnfase nas propriedades bioativas e potencial funcional. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
IV.	OBJECTIVES AND GOALS 

A. To promote the knowledge about brain diseases involving excitotoxicity. Study the involved brain mechanisms and neuroprotection strategies, with a multidisciplinary basic and clinical approach. 
1. To contribute to the understanding of the molecular, metabolic and cellular bases in several excitotoxic conditions, in human diseases and experimental animal models; 
2. To identify biochemical, electrophysiological and neuroimaging markers for the evaluation in experimental models and for the diagnosis and the prognosis of diseases associated with excitotoxicity; 
3. To characterize potential molecular, metabolic and cellular therapeutic targets in excitotoxic conditions; 
4. To propose strategies for neuroprotection, including pharmacological and/or non-pharmacological approaches for cerebral diseases that involve excitotoxicity. 

B. To promote training of highly qualified human resources in the subject at the post-graduate level. 
1. To form Master and PhD students in projects in the theme of this INCT linked to Post-Graduation Programs (PGPs) and research groups of the involved Institutions; 
2. To encourage the exchange and the experience of undergraduate and graduate students among consolidated centers research and with the emerging research groups of this Network institutions; 
3. To encourage the qualification of postdocs in the interface of the network Institutions, in order to enable a multidisciplinary approach of the various groups involved. 
4. To promote an effective interaction between basic and clinical research, creating a translational atmosphere in the investigation on brain diseases.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Construзгo de centro de pesquisa para estudo da origem fetal de doenзas prevalentes na vida adulta.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
O objetivo precнpuo do projeto de criaзгo do ?Centro para Estudo da Origem Fetal de Doenзas Prevalentes na Vida Adulta? й desenvolver a infra-estrutura de uma rede de laboratуrios integrados para investigar os mecanismos celulares e moleculares subjacentes ao aparecimento de doenзas prevalentes na vida adulta. O que norteia a construзгo desse centro de estudo й a elevada prevalкncia de desnutriзгo e anemia na nossa regiгo.
O fato mais preocupante, todavia, refere аs repercussхes desse quadro de desnutriзгo na infвncia e o aparecimento de doenзas prevalentes na vida adulta. A base teуrica para esta associaзгo entre desnutriзгo fetal/neonatal/infantil e obesidade na vida adulta vem sendo descrita em estudos epidemiolуgicos em todo o mundo. 
Particularmente os laboratуrios que serгo construнdos complementarгo os estudos epidemiolуgicos sobre desnutriзгo infantil, obesidade e doenзas correlatas realizados em nossa regiгo e nos quais o Centro de Ciкncias da Saъde, atravйs de seus Departamentos e Programas de Pуs-graduaзгo, participa ativamente. Dentro dessa rede, novas tecnologias e metodologias de abordagem de fenфmenos fisiolуgicos serгo implantadas, nomeadamente, as ferramentas da biologia molecular e de manipulaзхes gкnicas para o estudo funcional de macromolйculas.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Objetivo
Nos ъltimos anos, vбrios estudos tкm mostrado que a estimulaзгo elйtrica nervosa perifйrica repetitiva pode interferir no funcionamento do sistema nervoso central (SNC; J. Physiol. 523:503-513, 2000). Este trabalho avaliou, em ratos Wistar jovens (J; 35-45 dias de vida) e adultos (A; 95-105 dias pуs natal), se a eletroestimulaзгo perifйrica (EP), repetitiva aplicada durante o desenvolvimento do SNC (dos 7 aos 28 dias de vida), provoca mudanзas permanentes e/ou transitуrias na atividade elйtrica cortical, analisada por registros eletrofisiolуgicos do fenфmeno da depressгo alastrante cortical (DAC).

Os animais foram submetidos a sessхes diбrias de EP , de estнmulos elйtricos (pulsos de onda quadrada; 1,5ms; 10-40V) com freqькncia de 60 Hz (Grupo-60) ou 2 Hz (Grupo-2). Esta EP foi assimйtrica (sу no lado esquerdo do corpo), atravйs de 2 eletrodos nas patas esquerdas. Os ratos controles (Grupo-C) receberam eletrodos similares, mas nгo foram estimulados. Entre os 35 aos 45 (Grupo J) ou dos 95 aos 105 (Grupo A) dias de idade, os ratos foram submetidos ao registro da DAC (deflagrada com KCl a 2%), em 2 pontos de cada um dos hemisfйrios cerebrais (2h de registro em cada hemisfйrio). Sua velocidade de propagaзгo foi calculada com base no tempo gasto pela DAC para percorrer a distвncia entre os 2 pontos de registro. A estimulaзгo com 2 Hz, mas nгo com 60 Hz, tanto no grupo J quanto no A, reduziu as velocidade da DAC em relaзгo аs do grupo controle, no hemisfйrio contralateral ao hemicorpo estimulado (P<0,05). Nos animais estimulados, comparaзхes intragrupo mostraram que independente da idade as velocidades da DAC foram sempre menores no hemisfйrio contralateral а EP. Nos controles, essa diferenзa inter-hemisfйrica inexistiu.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Lasting facilitation of cortical spreading depression produced by 1Hz and 20Hz electrical cortical stimulation.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XX Reuniгo Anual da Federaзгo de Sociedades de Biologia Experimental/FESBE.
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DA-EDITORA: Federaзгo de Sociedades de Biologia Experimental/FESBE.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introduction:
 Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a non-invasive tool that can stimulate neural tissue in the living human brain. Although, the clinical applications of this technique have been increasing during the last decade, its mechanisms of action remain unknown. Cortical spreading depression (CSD) is an electrophysiological well-characterized technique to study brain excitability with documented abnormalities in various neurological diseases such as epilepsy or migraine. Herein, we explore, in the rat cerebral cortex, the question of whether repetitive electric stimulation increase cortical excitability as indexed by the CSD. Repetitive electrical stimulation was used instead of rTMS due to the inherent technical limitations of rTMS procedure used in rat studies.

Methods:
 Twelve Wistar rats were equaly divided into 3 groups according to the treatment: sham, 1 Hz and 20 Hz stimulation. Stimulation was applied to the left prefrontal cortex through a pair of epidurally implanted silver-wire electrodes. The treatment lasted for 2 days (4 sessions of stimulation ? total of 4800 pulses). Each session consisted of 1200 pulses delivered continuously (1Hz stimulation) or in trains of 3 seconds (5 seconds of interval - 20 Hz stimulation). The CSD-features were analyzed one day before and one day after treatment in both stimulated- (SH) and non-stimulated hemisphere (NSH).
 
Results:
 Analysis of variance with three factors, stimulation condition, stimulated hemisphere and time of evaluation, showed a significant interaction between them (F=13,68, p=0.005). Post-hoc analysis showed that 1 and 20 Hz repetitive electrical stimulation significantly increased the velocity of CSD in the SH (p=0.001 and p<0.0001, respectively, paired student t-test). Furthermore, 20 Hz treatment showed a greater effect on CSD compared to 1 Hz treatment (58% versus 16% increase in the CSD velocity, respectively). The NSH of rats that received 1 Hz and the NSH and SH o

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
OBJETIVO:
Tem sido demonstrado que a ativaзгo do sistema serotoninйrgico antagoniza a depressгo alastrante cortical (DA). O inibidor seletivo de recaptaзгo de serotonina, citalopram (CIT) teve evidente efeito quando aplicado topicamente no cуrtex, mas pouco efeito por via sistкmica durante 7 dias. Neste trabalho investigou-se se o tratamento sistкmico crфnico (21 dias) seria mais eficaz, bem como se a desnutriзгo precoce modificaria esse efeito.
Mйtodos: 
Ratos wistar adultos(250-350g) machos, desnutridos no aleitamento (D; n=9) ou normonutridos (N; n=12) receberam citalopram(20mg/kg/dia, i.p) por 21 dias a partir dos 90 dias de vida. Eles foram comparados a ratos controle, que receberam salina (SAL; 8D e 7N), ou nenhum tratamento (ingкnuos; 6D e 7N). O registro da DA foi realizado 18?22h apуs a ъltima aplicaзгo. A DA foi deflagrada com KCl 2% no cуrtex frontal e sua propagaзгo registrada em 2 pontos do cуrtex parietal, por 4h consecutivas. A velocidade de propagaзгo foi calculada a partir do tempo necessбrio para uma onda de DA percorrer a distвncia entre os 2 pontos de registro.

RESULTADOS:
O tratamento crфnico com CIT reduziu significativamente a velocidade da DA, (mйdia +desvio-padrгo, por h de registro, variando de 2,66±0,15 a 2,84±0,25mm/min) em comparaзгo com os grupos controle (SAL e ingкnuo; de 3,36±0,12 a 3,44±0,26), os quais nгo diferiram entre si. O mesmo efeito do CIT sobre a DA foi encontrado tambйm nos animais que sofreram desnutriзгo precoce (CIT, de 3,45±0,18 a 3,55±0,14; controles, de 4,53±0,26 a 4,70±0,25).

CONCLUSГO:
Os resultados sugerem que os efeitos do CIT sobre a DA sгo influenciados pela duraзгo do tratamento, mas nгo pelo estado nutricional.
Apoio financeiro: CNPq/PIBIC/FACEPE.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Shrimp carotenoids protect the cerebral cortex against the effects of ethanol on spreading depression.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: XX Reuniгo Anual da FeSBE - Federaзгo das Sociedades de Biologia Experimental

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Cortical spreading depression is a neural phenomenon present in several animal species. Spreading depression features, like velocity of propagation, depends on several chemical and metabolic factors, as for example, anti-oxidants. Here we studied spreading depression-velocity changes in weaned rat-pups born from dams treated on a daily basis, either during gestation or lactation, with a carotenoid ethanolic extract (30g/kg/day) prepared from shrimp waste (heads). These pups were compared with age-mated ones, whose mothers were treated either with the vehicle (ethanol) or with distilled water. Compared to the distilled water-group (mean values, in mm/min, per hour of recording ranging from 3.02±0.26 to 3.15±0.27 [treatment during gestation; n = 7], and from 3.03±0.25 to 3.22±0.30 [lactation; n = 11]), ethanol-treated rats displayed higher spreading depression-velocities (from 3.74±0.06 to 3.82±0.08 [gestation; n = 7], and from 4.26±0.32 to 4.33±0.34 [lactation; n = 11]; p < 0.05). Compared to the ethanol-group, carotenoid-treatment lead to lower spreading depression-velocities (p < 0.05), ranging from 3.38±0.09 to 3.42±0.12, n = 7 (gestation) and 3.58±0.13 to 3.62±0.17, n = 12 (lactation). Carotenoid-treatment during lactation was shown to be significantly more effective than that during gestation (p < 0.05), in lowering spreading depression-velocity. The results suggest a protective action of shrimp carotenoids against the ethanol effects on spreading depression. This protective effect could be related to the carotenoid antioxidant properties, as previously indicated by evidence showing spreading depression-effects of other antioxidants.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: NUTRITION, HYPERTHYROIDISM EARLY IN LIFE AND BRAIN DEVELOPMENT: AN STUDY IN JUST-WEANED RATS.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: It is known that early alterations of thyroid function interferes with cerebral development and physiology. In this work we investigated the effects of early treatment with thyroxin (T4) on the propagation of cortical spreading depression (SD) in weaned rats. Female adult Wistar rats fed a lab chow diet (CD; 23% protein) were treated with T4 (20ug/kg/day, single ip injection) during either gestation (group CDH-G) or during the first or third week of the lactation period (groups CDH-L1 and CDH-L3 respectively). They were compared with 3 control groups, injected at the same periods with saline solution (groups S-G, S-L1 and S-L3, respectively). One additional malnourished group was treated with T4 at L3, and another one was studied at the "naпve" condition (i.e., without receiving any injection or other kind of manipulation). Body weight and some dimensions (longitudinal body axis, as well as latero-lateral and antero-posterior skull axis) were obtained at days 2, 5, 10, 15, 20 and 25. From weaning (day 25) to day 35, the pups were submitted to the electrocorticogram- and slow potential change recordings of SD, which was elicited by KCl at the frontal cortex and recorded at 2 points of the parietal region. T4-treated rats presented reduction in body and brain weights. Compared to the controls, serum T3 levels were found to be reduced in the group treated during gestation and increased in those treated during lactation. Serum T4 levels changed in the opposite direction. The malnourished group presented lower body and brain weights, when compared to the well-nourished control. T4 treatment associated with malnutrition resulted in high mean SD-velocities, but the differences from the wellnourished group treated with T4 were not significant. In the groups CDH-G and CDH-L3 Impairment in body growth was not uniform, so that we found variable degrees of impairment between body- and skull growth parameters. The results indicate that T4 treatment early in life can alter develo

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
B.01.016
Glutamine supplementation during brain development facilitates cortical spreading depression
propagation in weaned young rats
Lima, D. S. C.1; Barboza, E. A.1; Souza, L. S.1; Duarte, R. A.1; Pires, R. B.1; Guedes, R. C. A.1 -
1Universidade Federal de Pernambuco - Nutriзгo
OBJECTIVE ? The amino acid glutamine (GLN) participates, in the brain, in the so-called ?glutamineglutamate cycle? and is the most abundant amino acid in cerebrospinal fluid, being likely to influence brain excitability. Recently it has been shown in the rat brain that GLN modulates epileptiform activity in vitro, provoking, in elevated concentrations, events resembling spreading depression (SD; Neurobiol. Dis.25:230, 2007). Here we investigated in weaned rats the effects of previous GLN oral supplementation, during the brain development period, on SD.
METHODS ? Male Wistar rat pups (n=10) received GLN (500mg/Kg/day) by gavage during postnatal days 7 to 27. At 30-40 days of life, they were submitted to a SD recording session during 4h, on 2 cortical parietal points of the right hemisphere. SD velocity propagation was calculated from the time required for a SD-wave to cross the inter-electrode distance.
RESULTS: GLN rats presented higher (P<0.05) SD propagation velocities (ranging, during the 4hrecording period, from 4.14±0.23 to 4.32±0.26 mm/min; mean±sd), as compared to water-treated controls (n=10; ranging from 3.71±0.20 to 3.76±0.24 mm/min). This water control group did not differ from a naпve control group (n=10) that was not submitted to the gavage procedure and presented SD-velocities ranging from 3.68±0.06 to 3.76±0.24 mm/min. A fourth group (n=9), treated with a ?placebo amino acid? (glycine) that is not involved in the ?glutamine-glutamate cycle?, also displayed SD-velocities in the control range (from 3.47±0.15 to 3.71±0.34 mm/min).
CONCLUSION: The results indicate that GLN supplementation during brain development facilitates cortical spreading depression propagation, as

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Treatment with tianeptine during development increases cortical spreading depression propagation in rats.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: I Congresso IBRO-LARC de Neurociкncias da Amйrica Latina, Caribe e Penнnsula Ibйrica - Neurolatam 2008.

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Luciana Maria Silva de Seixas Maia
AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: MAIA, L. M. S. DE S.

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Paula Catirina Pereira da Silva Germano

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
Previous work has demonstrated that cortical topic treatment with tianeptine, a reuptake serotonin enhancer, facilitates cortical spreading depression (CSD) propagation in adult rats (II Simpуsio do Instituto Internacional de Neurociкncias de Natal, 2007). In this study, systemic administration of tianeptine has been used, instead of topic application, in order to confirm its influence on CSD by using a clinically more important way of pharmacotherapy. Wistar rats were injected subcutaneously from postnatal day 2 to 24 with tianeptine (T; 5 or 10 mg/kg/d) or equivalent volume of saline solution (S). CSD was recorded immediately after weaning (25-30 days of life). The phenomenon was elicited every 20 min by KCl (2% solution) applied for 1 min to a point of the frontal region and its propagation was recorded at 2 points of the parietal cortex. Systemic administration of tianeptine significantly increased
(p<0.05) CSD velocities when compared to the S group (mean±SD of the 4h of recordings, in mm/min: 3.98±0.13, 4.61±0.38 and 3.79±0.19 for the groups T5, T10 and S, respectively). These results suggest that the serotoninergic system is putatively involved in CSD propagation mechanisms, reinforcing previous data with other serotoninergic drugs (Exp. Neurol. 200:275, 2006). By considering that important neurological diseases like epilepsy and migraine are related to serotoninergic processes, as well as to CSD, this study could contribute for future strategies of therapy against those diseases. Additionally, the possibility is raised, that tianeptine-induced reduction in the brain serotonin availability can be used as a tool to better understand brain function, concerning the serotoninergic system. 

Palavras- Chave: Tianeptine, Spreading depression, Serotonin, Development, Nervous system, Rat

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
B.04.023
IMPACT OF ESSENTIAL FATTY ACIDS RESTRICTION IN MAINTENANCE OF
CONNECTIONS IN THE RAT VISUAL SYSTEM
Velasco, P. C.1; MELIBEU,A.C.F.1; Campello-Costa, P.1; Guedes, R. C. A.2; Borba, J. M. C.2; Costa, B. L. S. A.3; Serfaty, C.1 - 1Universidade Federal Fluminense - Neurobiologia; 2Universidade Federal de Pernambuco - Nutriзгo; 3UFPE - Fisiologia e Farmacologia

The development of sensory neuronal circuitry occurs during a critical period when extensive axonal elimination and plasticity precede the stabilization of topographical representation. Among the mechanisms of synaptic maintenance, essential fatty acids (EFA) appear as important messengers, since the blockade arachidonic acid synthesis, induces sprouting in the retinotectal pathway of adult rats (Neuroscience,139:979, 2006). In the present study, we tested the effect of EFA restriction in the longterm stabilization of connections in the visual system and in a plasticity model following a contralateral retinal lesion. Lister Hooded female rats were fed during 5 weeks before mating (30g/day) with either a control (soy oil) or a restricted (coconut oil) diet. After birth, litters were fed until postnatal day 28 (PND 28) or PND 42 when they received an intraocular injection of HRP. Another group received a single retinal lesion at the temporal periphery at PND 21. Serial coronal brain sections (40μm) were processed according Mesulam?s protocol (1978). For statistical analysis we considered as significant differences of p<0.05. EFA restriction produced a significant increase in the optical density in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus, as a result of axonal sprouting outside the main terminal zones. In the intermediate
aspect of the stratum griseum superficial (SGS) we observed an increase in optical density of fibers at PND 28 and in PND 42. We also observed increased fiber density in the intercluster region indicating an intralaminar sprouting as well. After a contralateral retinal

C.01.072
Hindpaw cortical representation in the somatosensory S1 area in exercised pre-senescent Wistar Rats.
Batista-De-Oliveira, M.1; Amвncio-dos-Santos1; Araъjo, A. A.1; Lima, D. S. C.1; Abadie-Guedes, R.2; Almeida, I. N. F.3; Rocha, E. G.4; PEREIRA, A.5; Picanзo Diniz, C. W.6; Guedes, R. C. A.1 -
1Universidade Federal de Pernambuco - Nutriзгo; 2UFPE - Bioquimica; 3UFPA -
Morfologia; 4Universidade Federal do Parб - Instituto de Ciкncias Biolуgicas; 5UFPA -
ICB; 6Universidade Federal do Parб - Morfologia

Cortical neuron regeneration is an activity-dependent process whereby physical exercise may induce significant plastic changes. In the present report we studied the possible impact of exercise on the somatosensory cortical representation of the hindpaw in pre-senescent (16-22 month old) Wistar rats. Treadmill-exercised (for ninety days at 0.2m/s) (n=4) or sedentary (n=4) subjects, were anesthetized and the extracellular activity of small clusters of neurons was recorded with tungsten microelectrodes in the hind paw area of the primary somatosensory cortex (S1). The multiunit signal was amplified and fed to a
monitor and audio systems while delimiting receptive field borders with light stimulation of the skin. At the end of the experiment all animals were perfused through the aorta with saline (0.9%) followed by aldehyde fixatives. Brains were removed, cut and stained with cresyl-violet, Wisteria floribunda histochemistry and immunolabeled for GFAP and Neu-N. Bi-dimensional reconstructions of the penetration series were done for each animal using anatomical landmarks in superimposed sections. There was no significant difference between the exercised and sedentary groups in terms of both the size of receptive fields (5513.3±1556.6 vs 7242.3±2578.5) and the total area of the hind paw representation
(45087.0±13370.2 vs 530803.8±100299.1), both expressed in arbitrary units. However the areal measurements of the hind paw footprints in exercised (1.97 ± 0.17) r

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: REPETITIVE CORTICAL ELECTRICAL STIMULATION FACILITATES SPREADING DEPRESSION IN ADULT RATS SUBMITTED DURING BRAIN DEVELOPMENT TO DIFFERENT NUTRITIONAL CONDITIONS.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: It has been previously demonstrated that the repetitive cortical electric stimulation (rCES) increases cortical spreading depression (CSD) propagation in the stimulated hemisphere of early severe malnourished rats (IINN-ELS Annals 51:35, 2007). We here tested the possibility that another kind of nutritional restriction, which results in a moderate degree of malnutrition, could influence the rCES-effect on SD. The nutritional status was manipulated during lactation by increasing the litter size from 6 (control size) to 12 pups (large-size litters; group LS12). This moderate malnutrition group was compared with the severe malnutrition model (M-BRD), induced in sucklings by feeding their dams a low-protein diet (?Basic Regional Diet?, BRD, with 8% of protein). After weaning, nutritional recovery was performed by feeding the pups the standard lab-chow diet (with 23% protein). At 60 days of age, CSD was recorded on 2 cortical points of each hemisphere. After a 2-h ?baseline recording?, rCES (600 μA, 5ms, 1 Hz) was applied for 20 min on the left cortex with a bipolar electrode placed between the CSD recording electrodes. After rCES, CSD recording continued for 2 h. Compared to the control group, (mean ± sd: 284.03±15.18g), the malnourished ones presented lower body weights (210.81±16.69g and 272.41±13.76g for the M-BRD and LS12, respectively), on the CSD recording day. Malnutrition also increased CSD velocities of propagation (M-BRD > LS12 > control). In all groups, rCES increased the CSD velocity of propagation, in the stimulated hemisphere (mean ± sem: D-DBR, 13.19%±1.02; LS12, 10.13%±1.70; control, 25.70%±5.05). The data suggested a similar effect of rCES on CSD irrespective of the previous nutritional condition, during brain development. They also indicated that the moderate malnutrition model does not influence the rCES-effects on CSD. This effect seems to be due to the increase in the cortical excitability provoked by the electric stimulation. The data represen

C.03.004
Interaction nutrition-drug in the brain: neurophysiologic effects of dipyrone on
cortical spreading depression in early-malnourished adult rats
Amaral, A. P. B.1; Barbosa, M. S. S.2; Souza, V. C.2; Ramos, I. L. T.2; Santos, R. C. F.3; Guedes, R. C. A.1 - 1Universidade Federal de Pernambuco - Nutriзгo; 2Universidade Federal de Pernambuco - Nutricao; 3Universidade federal de Pernambuco - Departamento de Nutriзгo
Objectives: The effectiveness of some drugs in mammals can vary as a function of their
nutritional status (Ciкnc. Cult. 56:32-35 2004). The drug dipyrone (DP), besides its
analgesic and antithermic effects, has antiepileptic action in rats (Neuroreport 9:2415-
2421 1998). In this species, malnutrition, acting for short periods early in life, can
differentially modify the phenomenon of cortical spreading depression (CSD; Braz. J.
Med. Biol. Res. 30:663-670 1997). Considering the epilepsy-CSD relationships, as well
as the use of DP in children, we here investigated the impact of DP, applied in the 2nd,
3rd or 4th week of life, on CSD, in developing rats previously submitted to different
nutritional statuses.

litter size to 12 pups, as compared to the 72 well-nourished (W) controls (litters with 6
pups). In both nutritional groups half of the animals received, during 7 days, per gavage,
DP (300mg/kg/d) and the other half received saline. Both DP- and saline groups were
divided in three groups, according to the week of life (2nd, 3rd, or 4th week) in which
DP was applied. At 35-45 days of life, CSD was elicited with 2% KCl at the frontal
cortex and recorded at 2 points in the parietal region by recording the
electrocorticogram and the slow potential change of CSD.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Objectives: The effectiveness of some drugs in mammals can vary as a function of their nutritional status (Ciкnc. Cult. 56:32-35 2004). The drug dipyrone (DP), besides its analgesic and antithermic effects, has antiepileptic action in rats (Neuroreport 9:2415-2421 1998). In this species, malnutrition, acting for short periods early in life, can differentially modify the phenomenon of cortical spreading depression (CSD; Braz. J. Med. Biol. Res. 30:663-670 1997). Considering the epilepsy-CSD relationships, as well as the use of DP in children, we here investigated the impact of DP, applied in the 2nd, 3rd or 4th week of life, on CSD, in developing rats previously submitted to different nutritional statuses. Methods: Malnutrition (M) was produced in 72 rats during lactation by increasing the litter size to 12 pups, as compared to the 72 well-nourished (W) controls (litters with 6 pups). In both nutritional groups half of the animals received, during 7 days, per gavage, DP (300mg/kg/d) and the other half received saline. Both DP- and saline groups were divided in three groups, according to the week of life (2nd, 3rd, or 4th week) in which DP was applied. At 35-45 days of life, CSD was elicited with 2% KCl at the frontal cortex and recorded at 2 points in the parietal region by recording the electrocorticogram and the slow potential change of CSD. Results: In both W- and M-groups, DP-treatment increased (P<0.05) the CSD-velocities of propagation, as compared to the respective saline-controls. This effect was more intense when DP was applied at the fourth week of life, as compared to the second week. For the W and M saline-treated groups, the mean±sd velocities (in mm/min) were 3.70±0.11, 3.77±0.16 and 3.78±0.13 (W-groups) and 4.14±0.09, 4.13±0.09 and 4.11±0.07 (M-groups), for the animals treated in the 2nd, 3rd and 4th week of life. For the DP-treated groups, the means were 3.99±0.14, 4.03±0.16 and 4.30±0.14 (W-groups) and 4.46±0.18, 4.68±0.29 and 4.96±0.28 (M-groups). C

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: EXPOSURE OF DEVELOPING RATS TO ENVIRONMENTAL HYPERTHERMIA FACILITATES THE PROPAGATION OF CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
C.03.030
Exposure of Developing Rats to Environmental Hyperthermia Facilitates the Propagation of
Cortical Spreading Depression.
Santos, R. C. F.1; Gomes, K. B. A.2; Queiroz, P. M. A.2; Guedes, R. C. A.2 - 1Universidade federal de Pernambuco - Departamento de Nutriзгo; 2Universidade Federal de Pernambuco - Nutriзгo
Aims: Cortical spreading depression (CSD) is a brain response related to neural
excitability changes and to diseases like epilepsy and migraine. Exposure to a warm
environment can alter the neural excitability, changing brain eletrophysiological
features, which may be relevant to epilepsy genesis. Here we investigated the effects, on
brain CSD susceptibility, of exposing developing rats to a warm environment.
Methods
Wistar suckling rats (n=6), suckled by mothers fed a commercial diet with 23% protein,
were submitted from day 10 st to 29 st day of life to 15 daily sessions (5 sessions per
week during 3 weeks) of a warm environment (40±2°C), for 15, 20 and 30 min (in the
1st, 2nd and 3rd week, respectively). At 30-40 d of life, they were anesthetized
(urethane+chloralose; 1,000+40mg/kg ip) and the ECoG plus slow potential change
accompanying CSD were recorded on 2 parietal points for 4h.
Results: Early environmental hyperthermia resulted in higher CSD propagation
velocities (P<0.05), as compared to control rats (n=6) submitted to similar sessions at
room temperature (25±2°C). Mean CSD-velocities (in nm/min) ranged from 4.08±0.14
to 4.28±0.18 (experimental group) and from 3.74±0.16 to 3.75±0.16 (control group).
Conclusion: Environmental Hyperthermia during the suckling period facilitates CSD
propagation in the brain of young weaned rats, as judged by its high velocities,
suggesting that the warming episodes occurring during brain development effected
cortical susceptibility to CSD. The possible relationship with brain alterations due to
febrile seizures in children justify further investigation.
Palavras-Chave: Environmental hyperth

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: SENSORY DEPRIVATION BY VIBRISSAE REMOVAL LONG-LASTINGLY FACILITATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION PROPAGATION IN RATS.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: SENSORY DEPRIVATION BY VIBRISSAE REMOVAL LONG-LASTINGLY FACILITATES CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION PROPAGATION IN RATS.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Objectives: Deprivation of sensory input from whiskers, at various stages of development, can induce physiological, and often structural, changes that modify the circuitry of these sensory systems, altering their response properties following prolonged alterations in input activity. Here we investigated whether such morpho-physiological alterations would influence the propagation features of cortical spreading depression (CSD), in just-weaned and adult rats. Methods: Male Wistar rat pups had the right mystacial vibrissae removed followed by electrocauterization at postnatal days 2-3 (n=20), and were submitted to CSD recordings, during 4h, on 2 cortical points of both hemispheres at 30-40 days of life (n=10; young rats) and 90-120 days (n=10; adult rats). CSD velocities of propagation were calculated based on the time required for CSD to spread along the inter-electrode distance. Results: In young rats, CSD velocities (in mm/min) in the hemisphere contralateral to the vibrissae removal was higher (4.52±0.36), as compared to those in the ipsilateral hemisphere (3.84±0.20; P<0.05). This effect persisted until adult life, when the mean velocities for lesioned and controls were respectively 4.13±0.12 and 3.35±0.06. In age-matched controls, no inter-hemispheric differences in CSD velocities were found (mean values for the right and left hemispheres, respectively, of 3.80±0.22 and 3.77±0.20 for the young rats, and 3.41±0.10 and 3.40±0.10 for the adults). Conclusions: The results suggest that deprivation of sensory input from whiskers during brain development facilitates cortical spreading depression propagation in rats. Since this effect persisted until adulthood, it is tempting to suggest that it is permanent, or at least long-lasting.

O nervo isquiбtico й formado por fibras aferentes somбticas e eferentes somбticas e autonфmicas. Й o maior nervo do corpo humano e do rato, distribuindo-se extensamente aos membros inferiores. O nervo vestнbulo-coclear do rato possui caracterнsticas morfolуgicas nгo encontradas em outros nervos perifйricos; й um nervo aferente especial que possui uma atividade elйtrica espontвnea, de vital importвncia. Nгo foram encontradas evidкncias sobre a influкncia do diabete e suas interaзхes patolуgicas com esse nervo, que pudessem provocar surdez ou alteraзхes neurossensoriais. A avaliaзгo descritiva atravйs da microscopia eletrфnica de transmissгo realizada no presente estudo, evidencia informaзхes fundamentais, que precedem o estudo das alteraзхes que ocorrem em modelos experimentais de neuropatias do VIII nervo craniano e as doenзas ou lesхes que possam afetar o homem. Mais ainda, alteraзхes do VIII nervo craniano decorrente do diabete experimental estгo sendo descritas pela primeira vez na literatura.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Nutritional restricition of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids disrupts fine topography of retinal axons in the rat superior colliculus.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Nutritional restricition of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids disrupts fine topography of retinal axons in the rat superior colliculus.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 39th Annual Meeting of the Society for Neurosciences

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Belmira Lara da Silveira Andrade da Costa

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:

The development of sensory systems occurs during a critical period when extensive axonal elimination and plasticity are involved in the fine organization of sensory topographical maps. Essential fatty acids (EFAs) appear as precursors of signaling molecules including retrograde messengers. Here, we tested the effect of EFAs nutritional restriction in the structure of retinal terminal fields in the rodent superior colliculus. We also tested EFAs deprivation on the expression of AMPA receptor subunits GluR1 and GluR2 and in phosphorylated GAP-43 protein. Female Lister Hooded rats were fed during 5 weeks before mating with either control (soy oil) or restricted (coconut oil) diets. After birth, litters were fed until postnatal day 28 (PND 28) or PND 42 when they received an intraocular injection of anterograde neuronal tracer (HRP). Another group received a single retinal lesion at the temporal periphery at PND 21. Western blot tests were used to determine expression of GLUR1, GLUR2 and pGAP43. EFAs restriction produced a significant increase in the optical density in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus, as a result of axonal sprouting outside the main terminal zones. Increased optical density was observed in the intermediate and ventral aspects of the stratum griseum superficiale (SGS) at PND 28 and PND 42. After a contralateral retinal lesion, the EFAs-restricted group displayed increased sprouting of intact axons at the lesion site as compared to the control group. Moreover, EFAs restriction decreased pGAP-43 expression and increased GluR1 and GluR2 subunits expression of the glutamate AMPA receptor. The data indicate that food restriction of EFAs induces a disruption in the topographical map organization and abnormal plasticity of retinotectal axons. This effect was correlated to increased turnover/expression in AMPA receptors and decreased pGAP43 protein and is consistent with a role for EFAs as precursors of stabilizing synaptic agents

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Omega-3 fatty acids nutritional restriction alters the morphofunctional differentiation of the rat retina

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Congresso da SBNeC

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Belmira Lara da Silveira Andrade da Costa

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Introduction: During the development of the mammalian visual system,
synaptic refinement depends on spontaneous electric activity of retinal ganglion
cells (RGCs), mostly through GABAergic and cholinergic inputs until postnatal
day 12 (DPN 12). Essential fatty acids (EFAs), accumulated during fetal period
and neonatal development, appear as precursors of signaling molecules
including retrograde messengers and transcription factors. Docosahexaenoic
acid (DHA), the final bioactive lipid of the omega-3 fatty acids family chain, is
the main polyunsaturated fatty acid in the brain and retina and exerts their
effects on brain function through various mechanisms, including some involved
in the modulation of glutamate receptors and trophic factors. Here, we tested
the effect of omega-3 fatty acids in the development of retinal morphology,
particularly, the differentiation of photoreceptors and the cholinergic and
GABAergic markers involved in spontaneous activity during the critical period.
Methods: Female Lister Hooded rats were fed during 5 weeks before mating
with either control (soy oil) or restricted (coconut oil) diets. After birth, litters
were fed (30g/day/animal) until postnatal day (PND) 7, 14 and 21. Sections
were labeled with antibodies to photoreceptors, cholinergic and GABAergic
markers (anti-rhodopsin, anti-vChat and anti-GABA, respectively). Retinae were
also stained with either cresyl violet or neutral red.
Results: The morphological analysis of retinal tissue revealed a significant
reduction in the thickness in the outer nuclear and inner plexiform layers as
compared to control sections at PND14. EFAs restriction resulted in the
reduction of rhodopsin expression at PND 7 and PND 14. Also, restricted EFAs
restriction resulted in decreased immunoreactivity for the acetylcholine
transporter (vChat) from PND7-21 at the inner plexiform layer. In the
experimental group, GABA immunoreactivity in the inner nuclear and plexiform
layers w

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Omega-3 fatty acids restriction alters topographical fine tuning and induces abnormal plasticity of retinal axons in the rat superior colliculus

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Belmira Lara da Silveira Andrade da Costa

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
Resumo:
The development of sensory systems occurs during a critical period when extensive axonal elimination and plasticity are involved in the fine organization of topographical maps. Essential fatty acids (EFAs) appear as precursors of signaling molecules including retrograde messengers which are involved in modulation of gene expression and regulation of neurotransmitter synthesis and release. α-Linolenic (ω-3) are considered EFAs, since the dietary intake is the only source available. These acids are precursors of long chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (LCPUFA) like docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), which are highly accumulated during fetal period and neonatal development in the brain and retina. In the present study, we tested the effect of DHA nutritional restriction in the structure of retinal terminal fields in the rodent superior colliculus (SC). We also tested DHA deprivation on the expression of AMPA receptor subunits GluR1 and GluR2 and in phosphorylated form of GAP-43 protein (pGAP43). Female Lister Hooded rats were fed (30g/day/animal) during 5 weeks before mating with either control (soy oil) or restricted (coconut oil) diets. After birth, litters were fed until postnatal day 13 (PND13), PND28 or PND 42 when they received an intraocular injection of anterograde neuronal tracer (HRP). Another group received a single retinal lesion at the temporal periphery at PND 21. Western blot tests were used to determine the protein content of GLUR1, GLUR2 and pGAP43 in the visual layers of the SC. DHA restriction produced a significant increase in the optical density in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus, as a result of axonal sprouting outside the main terminal zones. Increased optical density was observed in the intermediate and ventral aspects
of the stratum griseum superficiale (SGS) at PND13. The same results were seen outside critical period (PND28 and PND42), suggesting a permanent disturbance in axonal connectivity. After a contralat

Resumo:

OBJETIVO: O tratamento precoce com Propiltiouracil (PTU) produz hipotiroidismo, com potenciais repercussхes sobre o desenvolvimento neural. Do mesmo modo a desnutriзгo resulta em alteraзхes no Sistema Nervoso Central e no comportamento A estimulaзгo sensorial precoce pode tambйm influenciar esse desenvolvimento. Neste trabalho, avaliou-se, em ratos jovens desnutridos, o efeito do PTU, associado ou nгo com a estimulaзгo tбtil, sobre o comportamento no Labirinto em Cruz Elevado (LCE), como meio de avaliar a ansiedade.
MЙTODO E RESULTADOS: Ratas Wistar, que recebiam durante a lactaзгo uma dieta multicarencial, a Dieta Bбsica Regional (DBR), foram injetadas ip., do 17o dia de gestaзгo atй o 15o dia da lactaзгo, com Propiltiouracil (8,0 mg/kg; grupo PTU; n=21), ou com soluзгo salina (grupo controle [C]; n=22). Em cada grupo, alguns dos filhotes machos receberam, do 1o ao 35o dias de vida, estimulaзгo tбtil (handling por 3 min; grupos E; n=17C e 12PTU) e outros permaneceram nгo-estimulados (grupos NE; n=5C e 9PTU), originando os 4 grupos deste estudo. No 35o dia, foram submetidos por 5 minutos ao LCE. Nos grupos PTU, os dados (mйdiaEPM) mostraram diminuiзгo significativa (p≤ 0,05) no nъmero de entradas nos braзos abertos (EBA: PTU-E 7,92  0,89 e PTU-NE 7,33 1,04), em comparaзгo com os C (CE 10,29  0,82 e CNE 9,8  1,46), bem como, uma diminuiзгo da freqькncia de entradas nos braзos fechados (EBF: PTU-E 7,08  0,73 e PTU-NE 6,89 0,56), em relaзгo aos C (CE 10,59  0,73 e CNE 11,4  1,57). Quanto a exploraзгo dos segmentos do braзo aberto, o tratamento com PTU reduziu a exploraзгo do segmento 1, mais prуximo da бrea central (SEG1: PTU-E 1,67  0,33 e PTU-NE 2,44 0,47), quando comparado aos C (CE 3,94  0,34 e CNE 4,2  0,66).
CONCLUSХES: O tratamento precoce com PTU em animais desnutridos sugere aumento da ansiedade e/ou diminuiзгo da impulsividade.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Microglial response in aged rats after early undernourishment/reduced maternal care and late exercise: stereological analysis of the dentate gyrus.
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Microglial response in aged rats after early undernourishment/reduced maternal care and late exercise: stereological analysis of the dentate gyrus.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 10th European Meeting on Glial Cells in Health and Disease

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
It is not known whether early in life undernourishment/reduced maternal care or a sedentary lifestyle influence the innate immune cells of the CNS. We tested whether microglial-induced changes by early undernourishment/reduced maternal care were aggravated by aging, and whether exercise late in life reduced these effects. Rats suckled in litters of six (well-nourishment/normal maternal care, W) or 12 (undernourishment/reduced maternal care, U) pups/mother were raised sedentarily in groups of 2-3 from the 21st post-natal day onwards. At 20 months of age, half of the sedentary rats underwent 20 min of daily treadmill exercise for three months, while the others remained sedentary. The brains were processed for microglia immunolabeling. An unbiased stereological method was applied to estimate the number of microglia in dentate gyrus. We found that undernourishment/reduced maternal care and sedentary life-style leads to a significant increase in microglia number in all layers of dentate gyrus. In addition later-in-life experience-dependent plasticity reduced the number of microglias in both W and U rats suggesting that exercise offsets some of the effects of a sedentary lifespan but did not influence the innate immune cells of the brain to restore their number to that associated with early well-nourishment/normal maternal care.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Characterization of monossodium glutamate action on cortical spreading depression in exercised and sedentary developing rats
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Characterization of monossodium glutamate action on cortical spreading depression in exercised and sedentary developing rats

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: I Congresso FALAN (Federaзгo das Assoc. Latino-Americanas de Neurociкncias

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims: Monossodium glutamate (MSG) is a flavoring agent that is also a neuroexcitatory amino acid harmful to the central nervous system and neuronal cells. In rats, the administration of MSG during the neonatal period results in acute degenaration of some cephalic nuclei leading to obesity, sexual disfunction, stunt, behavioral deficit, damaged cardiovascular control and signs of neuroendocrine obesity. Here we investigated the electrophysiological effects of MSG by characterizing the changes in the brain excitability-related phenomenon designated as cortical spreading depression (CSD). In addition, we also studied the positive impact of physical exercise on the MSG actions on CSD.
Methods: Wistar rats pups received MSG (4g/kg; n=25; group MSG-4) or (2g/kg; n=22; group MSG-2), or saline (n=23), or no treatment (naпve group; n=11) every two days in the first 14 days of postnatal life. After weaning, the three groups were subdivided in exercised (treadmill running, 3 weeks, 5 days/week for 30 min; n=34), or sedentary (n =24). Two days after training was completed, animals were anesthetized, CSD was elicited by KCl and electrophysiologically recorded during 4h. 
Results: The group MSG-4 presented mean velocities (in mm/min) significantly higher (4.59±0.34), when compared with the saline (3.84±0.20) or the naпve group (3.71±0.8). Physical exercise reduced CSD velocities both in the saline and the MSG groups (Saline Exercised: 3.27±0.26; Naпve Exercised: 3.25±0.19; MSG-4 exercised: 4.05±0.18 mm/min; P<0.05; ANOVA plus Tukey test). The group treated with MSG-2 presented velocities (3.75±0.10; Exercised: 3.49±0.19), similar to the groups saline and naпve.
Conclusions: MSG (4g/kg) administered to rats during brain development facilitates CSD propagation in the cerebral cortex. The physical exercise decelerates CSD propagation. No MSG-exercise interaction could be demonstrated. Data suggest caution in the use of MSG as flavoring, mainly in developing organisms, and point

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Aging-dependent brain electrophysiological effects in rats after distinct lactation conditions, and treadmill exercise: a spreading depression analysis
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Aging-dependent brain electrophysiological effects in rats after distinct lactation conditions, and treadmill exercise: a spreading depression analysis

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: I Congresso FALAN (Federaзгo das Assoc. Latino-Americanas de Neurociкncias

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract
The aging-related neurophysiologic alterations are a matter of growing concern in gerontology. Physical exercise has been therapeutically employed to attenuate the aging-associated deleterious neurological changes. The aging process, as well as the effects of treadmill exercise on brain excitability, can be influenced by the nutritional demands during lactation. Herein we investigated whether physical exercise, lactation conditions and the aging process can modulate brain electrophysiology, as indexed by the excitability-related phenomenon known as cortical spreading depression (CSD). Wistar male rats were suckled in litters with 12 or 6 pups, constituting two groups, denominated L12 and L6, with different lactation conditions. Each group was subdivided into young, adult and aged groups (respectively 45?60, 120?130 and 600?700 days old). Part of each age-group was exercised (treadmill) and the other part remained sedentary. In the adult age-group exercised rats were subdivided in exercised early in life and at adulthood. In the aged group, exercised rats were subdivided in exercised early in life, at adulthood and at elderly. In the L6 groups the mean CSD velocity in mm/min ranged from 2.57±0.24 in the aged- to 3.67±0.13 in the young rats, indicating a decelerating effect of aging. The L12 condition accelerated CSD with velocities ranging from 3.11±0.21 to 4.35±0.16 in aged and young rats, respectively, while treadmill exercise decelerated it in both L6 groups (range: 3.02±0.19 to 2.57±0.24) and L12 groups (3.32±0.16 to 3.11±0.21), with an aging/lactation condition interaction and aging/exercise-timing interaction seen in the aged group. Furthermore, aging led to a significant failure of CSD propagation. The results contribute to the comprehension of the underlying mechanisms by which exercising and aging influence brain electrophysiological functioning, previously associated with distinct lactation conditions during the period of brain development. INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:

The aging process, as well as the effects of treadmill exercise on brain excitability, can be influenced by the nutritional demands during lactation. Herein we investigated whether physical exercise, lactation conditions and the aging process can modulate brain electrophysiology, as indexed by the excitability-related phenomenon known as cortical spreading depression (CSD). Wistar male rats were suckled in litters with 12 or 6 pups, constituting two groups, denominated L12 and L6, with different lactation conditions. Each group was subdivided into young, adult and aged groups (respectively 45?60, 120?130 and 600?700 days old). Part of each age-group was exercised (treadmill) and the other part remained sedentary. In the adult age-group exercised rats were subdivided in exercised early in life and at adulthood. In the aged group, exercised rats were subdivided in exercised early in life, at adulthood and at elderly. In the L6 groups the mean CSD velocity in mm/min ranged from 2.57±0.24 in the aged- to 3.67±0.13 in the young rats, indicating a decelerating effect of aging. The L12 condition accelerated CSD with velocities ranging from 3.11±0.21 to 4.35±0.16 in aged and young rats, respectively, while treadmill exercise decelerated it in both L6 groups (range: 3.02±0.19 to 2.57±0.24) and L12 groups (3.32±0.16 to 3.11±0.21), with an aging/lactation condition interaction and aging/exercise-timing interaction seen in the aged group. Furthermore, aging led to a significant failure of CSD propagation. The results contribute to the comprehension of the underlying mechanisms by which exercising and aging influence brain electrophysiological functioning, previously associated with distinct lactation conditions during the period of brain development. DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Effects of ovarian hormones on cortical spreading depression. A topical cerebral application study in female adult rats
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Effects of ovarian hormones on cortical spreading depression. A topical cerebral application study in female adult rats

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: I Congresso FALAN (Federaзгo das Assoc. Latino-Americanas de Neurociкncias

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims:
Nowadays it is known that gonadal steroid hormones as progesterone and estradiol when unbalanced, exerts several neural alterations, particularly in those areas involved in sexual behavior as the preoptic area and the hypothalamus. There is also evidence of a neuroprotective effect of estradiol and progesterone applied just after ischemia in the central nervous system (Ulbrich et al 2012). 
The brain of mammals is one important target organ for the action of estrogen and progesterone hormones that cross the blood-brain barrier and exert electrophysiological effects on the brain, some of which depending on the excitability mechanisms. In vitro studies suggest a facilitatory influence of estrogen and progesterone on the phenomenon designated as Cortical Spreading Depression (CSD) in adult rats (Neurobiol. Dis. 25:27, 2007). Here we have electrophysiologically addressed this issue by characterizing in vivo, alterations in the brain ability to propagate CSD in female adult rats. CSD has been used as a physiological index to analyze the effects of the estrogen and progesterone topically applied in the cerebral cortex. 
Methods: Wistar female adult rats (90-120 days old) underwent 10 min topical application of β-estradiol (10 mg/ml; n =6) or progesterone (131,5mg/ml; n=6) over a circular cortical region (3?4 mm diameter) on the intact dura-mater. The CSD recording sessions lasted 5-6 h, and hormone solutions were applied during the last 10 min of the 20-min interval kept between two consecutive KCl-stimulations (used to elicit CSD). In each animal, the CSD propagation was evaluated before and after hormones application. Only animals in the proestrous phase of the estrous cycle were used.
Results: Compared to the basal values (3.30±0.13 and 3.17±0.11 for the progesterone and estradiol groups, respectively), the hormone application significantly increased the CSD velocity (to 3.57±0.27 and 3.47±0.22, respectively). After the β-estradiol or progesterone

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: ANTIOXIDANT α-TOCOPHEROL ANTAGONIZES ETHANOL EFFECTS ON THE CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN JUVENIL AND ADULT RATS
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: ANTIOXIDANT α-TOCOPHEROL ANTAGONIZES ETHANOL EFFECTS ON THE CORTICAL SPREADING DEPRESSION IN JUVENIL AND ADULT RATS

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: I Congresso FALAN (Federaзгo das Assoc. Latino-Americanas de Neurociкncias

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Objectives: We have previously demonstrated in rats that acute and chronic treatment with ethanol respectively decelerated and accelerated the propagation of cortical spreading depression (CSD), and the antioxidant carotenoid astaxanthin antagonized such effects (Abadie-Guedes et al, 2008; 2012). Here we investigated whether non-carotenoid antioxidant molecules could also promote such effect, by testing the alpha-tocopherol (Toc).
Methods: Male Wistar adult rats of two age-groups (juvenile [J]; 60-80 days, and adult [A]; 150-165 days; n=8-10 for each group) received per gavage chronic treatment (21 days) with 3g/kg/d ethanol alone, or combined with 85ug/kg/d of Toc, or only vehicle (olive oil for Toc and water for ethanol). Under urethane+chloralose anesthesia, the CSD was recorded in two points of the cortical surface during 4h and the CSD velocity of propagation was calculated, based on the time spent for CSD to pass the interelectrode distance.
Results: In both age-groups, ethanol-treated rats displayed significantly higher CSD-velocities (in mm/min: J=4.37±0.31; A=3.90±0.28), compared to the vehicle groups (J=3.27±0.06; A=3.19±0.13). Addition of Toc to the ethanol treatment reduced CSD velocities to the levels of the vehicle groups (J=3.25±0.08; A=3.34±0.09) (P<0.05; ANOVA plus Tukey test).
Conclusion: Data reinforce the role of antioxidants on brain processes involved in CSD, and also indicate that the action of antioxidants on CSD is not a particular property of carotenoids, but rather a general feature of antioxidant molecules.

Aging has been associated to neuroinflammation in the central nervous
system, however it is not known whether microglial changes induced
by aging are affected by early effects, such as litter size and sedentary
life style. In addition, the lateral septum has been recognized by its
complementary role in the memory processing for tasks of object recognition
for identity and spatial location. In the present report, we investigated
whether aging cognitive decline and microglial morphological
changes in the lateral septal region are influenced by changing litter
size early in life and by a sedentary life style. To assess these questions,
Wistar rats suckled in litters of either six or 12 pups per dam
were raised sedentarily in groups of 2 up to 3, from the 21st post-natal
day onwards. At 4 (young adult) or 23 (aged) months-old, half of the
sedentary rats underwent progressive daily treadmill exercise for five
weeks, while the others remained sedentary. After performing the tests
of recognition for spatial localization and object identity all of the animals
were sacrificed and their brains were processed for selective
mi

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
T03-13A = TREATMENT EARLY IN LIFE WITH THE LECTIN CONA DECELERATES SPREADING DEPRESSION IN WELL-NOURISHED AND EARLY-MALNOURISHED ADULT RATS
G. S. Ferreira Soares, L. Cabral Cavalcanti, R.C. A. Guedes
Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Recife, Brazil

Early nutritional insults have important effects on neural and glial electrophysiological activity because nutrients regulate brain development during early postnatal life, when neural and glial cells present higher degree of plasticity. Herein we characterized in adult rats the electrophysiological changes caused by the systemic treatment early in life with the lectin ConA by recording the electrophysiological phenomenon of cortical spreading depression (CSD). Additionally, we evaluated the impact of early nutritional deficiency on the CSD effects of ConA. 
Methods: Two nutritionally distinct groups of male newborn rats ? well-nourished (W; n = 26) and malnourished (M; n = 33) were treated from the 5th to the 24th day of postnatal life with daily intraperitoneal injections of saline (Sal) or ConA (Sigma-Aldrich) at doses of 1 mg/kg (group W-L1 and M-L1) or 10 mg/kg (Groups W-L10 and M-L10). Two groups of ?naive? (non-injected) pups were used as additional controls. When the pups reached adult age (90?120 days), under ip anesthesia (1 g/kg urethane140 mg/kg chloralose) they were submitted to the CSD recording (ECoG and slow potential change) in two points of the parietal cortical surface. CSD was triggered every 20 minutes by applying 2% KCl for 1 min at a point in the frontal cortex. This study was approved by the ethics committee of our University, Case No.:23076.031272/2010-53.
Results: Compared to W-Sal controls (mean ± sd velocity in mm/min = 3.41 ± 0.10), M-Sal rats presented significantly higher velocities (4.26 ± 0.16; p < 0.05). In both nutritional conditions L1 and L10 treated groups presented significantly lower CSD velocities (3.12 ± 0.14 and 2.82 ± 0.18 for the W-L1 and W-L10, respectively, and 3.74

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
A vitamina C, ou бcido ascуrbico (AA) й um nutriente encontrado em grande concentraзгo no cйrebro, sendo amplamente conhecido por sua aзгo antioxidante. Seu efeito sobre o sistema nervoso central parece ser dependente da dose empregada, podendo, sob certas condiзхes, facilitar a oxidaзгo ao invйs de agir como antioxidante. Em estudo anterior (Neurosci. Lett. 496:191, 2011), o tratamento com 60 mg/kg/dia durante 3 semanas facilitou a propagaзгo da depressгo alastrante cortical (DAC); entretanto, nгo se conhecia o efeito de doses menores ou maiores.
Objetivo: Avaliar, em ratos albinos, os efeitos eletrofisiolуgicos da administraзгo crфnica de crescentes doses de vitamina C (30, 60 e 120 mg/kg/dia) sobre o sistema nervoso em desenvolvimento, atravйs do fenфmeno da DAC.
Mйtodos: Ratos Wistar (n=53) foram distribuнdos em 5 grupos experimentais, que receberam diariamente, do 7є ao 28є dia de vida, os seguintes tratamentos por gavagem: soluзгo salina (n= 9) ou vitamina C, em diferentes doses (30, 60 e 120 mg/kg/dia; n= 15, 6 e 12, respectivamente). Um quinto grupo nгo recebeu tratamento por gavagem, sendo denominado como naпve (ingкnuo; n=11). Entre 30 e 40 dias de idade, os animais foram anestesiados e submetidos ao registro eletrofisiolуgico da DAC, em 2 pontos da superfнcie cortical direita, por 4 horas. A DAC foi deflagrada a cada 20 minutos por estimulaзгo de um ponto cortical com KCl a 2%. Por outo lado, o exercнcio fнsico induz efeitos positivos no sistema nervoso de mamнferos. Nosso objetivo com este estudo, foi investigar, em ratos tratados com MSG e/ou exercнcio fнsico em esteira, a reaзгo astrocitбria expressa pela imuno-marcaзгo com anticorpos anti GFAP no cуrtex motor. Ratos Wistar ( n=4-5 por cada grupo), receberam MSG (2 ou 4g/kg, respectivamente; grupos MSG-2 e MSG-4), ou soluзгo salina , ou nenhum tratamento (grupo ingкnuo) a cada dois dias, nos primeiros 14 dias de vida pуs-natal. Apуs o desmame, os trкs grupos foram subdivididos em exercitados (esteira motorizada, 3 semanas, 5 dias/semana, durante 30 minutos, ou sedentбrios. Dois dias apуs o final do exercнcio, os cйrebros foram perfundidos e crioprotegidos. Cortes de 40 micrфmetros de espessura foram processados para imuno-marcaзгo de cйlulas astrocitбrias (com anticorpo anti-GFAP). Comparado ao grupo salina, os animais tratados com MSG 2g-4g/kg apresentaram um aumento de imunorreatividade com diferenзa significativa entre eles, mostrando um aumento do gurpo 4g/kg comparado com o grupo de 2 g/kg, sendo o mesmo resultado para os grupos sedentбrios e exercitados. Nos grupos tratados com MSG, o exercнcio fнsico exerceu influкncia aumentando a porcentagem de бrea marcada; efeito oposto ocorreu em relaзгo ao grupo salina. No Experimento 2 (tratamento na vida adulta), houve efeito significativo da exposiзгo а sacarose (PE e NPE - F(1,28)=5,737, p<0,05), e da interaзгo exposiзгo X droga (F(1,28)=8,336, p<0,01). Os dados revelaram efeito LI apenas nos animais tratados com SAL (razхes de supressгo: PE=0,75±0,05 e NPE=0,28±0,06). A LI foi abolida nos animais tratados com CAF, durante as fases do pro

Isso pode comprometer funзхes neuropsнquicas, como a atenзгo. A Inibiзгo Latente (LI) й um modelo experimental para o estudo da atenзгo. Os animais foram subdivididos em 6 grupos: MB PE (n=8); MB NPE (n=8); CASEН 23% PE (n=10); CASEН 23% NPE (n=10); CASEН 8% PE (n=10) e CASEН 8% NPE (n=10). INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
INTRODUЗГO: O sistema nervoso central dos mamнferos й um importante уrgгo alvo dos hormфnios ovarianos desde o seu desenvolvimento а idade adulta. Eles atravessam livremente a barreira hematoencefбlica e exercem efeitos profundos sobre a excitabilidade cerebral. Em estudo prйvio (Intern.J.Dev.Neurosci. 30:405, 2012) demonstramos em ratas que a ovariectomia no inнcio da vida reduz a propagaзгo do fenфmeno denominado Depressгo Alastrante Cortical (DAC) na idade adulta. Um estudo in vitro em ratos adultos (Neurobiol. Dis. 25:27, 2007) sugere uma possнvel influкncia facilitadora, dose-dependente, da progesterona sobre a DAC.
OBJETIVOS: Neste estudo objetivou-se caracterizar eletrofisiologicamente, in vivo, alteraзхes na capacidade cerebral de propagar DAC em ratas adultas tratadas com progesterona no inнcio da vida, como нndice dos efeitos da aplicaзгo sistкmica de progesterona durante o desenvolvimento sobre a eletrofisiologia cerebral da rata adulta.
MЙTODOS: Um grupo de ratas Wistar recebeu por via intraperitoneal (dos 7 aos 21 dias de vida, em dias alternados) progesterona (50µg/kg; n=8) e foi comparado a grupos injetados com o veнculo (azeite de oliva; grupo V; n=8) ou sem tratamento (?ingкnuo?; grupo I; n=12). Aos 90-120 dias de idade, foram submetidas ao registro da DAC, em 2 pontos corticais por 4 h. Em todos os experimentos, os registros da DAC foram feitos sempre na fase de proestro. A anбlise estatнstica foi feita com ANOVA seguida do Teste de Holm-Sidak, com nнvel de significвncia P<0,05. Aprovado pelo Comitк de Йtica. Processo nє 23076.046121/2011-81.
RESULTADOS: O grupo que recebeu progesterona apresentou velocidade mйdia de propagaзгo da DAC (3,91±0,26 mm/min) significantemente maior (P<0,05) do que as dos grupos V (3,38±0,09) e I (3,33±0,12). 
CONCLUSГO: O tratamento sistкmico com progesterona durante o perнodo do desenvolvimento cerebral estб associado com a aceleraзгo da DAC no cйrebro adulto, indicando um efeito facilitador de longo prazo. Sugerim

Aos 90-120 dias de idade, foram submetidas ao registro da DAC, em 2 pontos corticais por 4 h. Em todos os experimentos, os registros da DAC foram feitos sempre na fase de proestro. A anбlise estatнstica foi feita com ANOVA seguida do Teste de Holm-Sidak, com nнvel de significвncia P<0,05. Aprovado pelo Comitк de Йtica. Processo nє 23076.046121/2011-81.

Introduзгo: Evidкncias cientнficas demonstram efeitos positivos do exercнcio fнsico sobre o cйrebro, podendo melhorar a funзгo cognitiva e influenciar a excitabilidade neuronal. A depressгo alastrante cortical (DAC) e a potenciaзгo de longa duraзгo (LTP) sгo fenфmenos neurais relacionados com a excitabilidade cerebral. Apуs 3 dias de adaptaзгo (nadando 2, 5 e 10 min respectivamente); descansam 2 dias e nadam nos 5 dias seguintes 15, 20, 25, 30 e 40 min/dia; mais 2 d de descanso e terminam com 40 min/dia por mais 5 d. Introduзгo: Glutamato monossуdico (MSG) й utilizado mundialmente como um intensificador de sabor dos alimentos. Em animais, seu uso durante o desenvolvimento pode afetar o desenvolvimento e funзхes neurais. Demonstramos anteriormente (Int. J. Develop. Neurosci. 33:98, 2014) que a administraзгo repetida de MSG em ratos no perнodo neonatal facilita a propagaзгo do fenфmeno da Depressгo Alastrante Cortical (DAC) e que o exercнcio fнsico atenua esse efeito. No entanto, nada se sabe sobre efeitos agudos no cйrebro adulto.

Adicionalmente, analisou-se o impacto benйfico da atividade fнsica sobre esse efeito.

Apуs o desmame, os grupos foram subdivididos em Exercitados (corrida em esteira motorizada, por 3 semanas, 5 dias/semana, durante 30 minutos; n=12 MSG e 7 salina), ou sedentбrios (n=11 MSG e 6 salina). O mesmo procedimento foi realizado no ponto 2. Foram comparadas as velocidades da DAC antes e apуs a aplicaзгo tуpica de MSG.
Resultados: Ao contrбrio do tratamento sistкmico, a aplicaзгo tуpica do MSG reduziu reversivelmente a velocidade da DAC, tanto no grupo sedentбrio quanto no exercitado. No grupo MSG sedentбrio, as velocidades na sequкn

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Low omega-3/DHA containing diets delays axonal elimination and the differentiation of cholinergic markers in the rodent visual system
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Low omega-3/DHA containing diets delays axonal elimination and the differentiation of cholinergic markers in the rodent visual system

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: Society for Neurosciences Annual Meeting - 2014

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Belmira Lara da Silveira Andrade da Costa

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Abstract:
Visual subcortical connections develop terminal field specificities through the selective elimination of misplaced axons and the maintenance of correct axonal branches, processes that underlie the use-dependent fine-tuning of topographical maps. In the present work, we studied the impact of a dietary restriction of omega-3 fatty acids on the development of eye specific segregation and topographical specificity of retinofugal pathways. We also studied the impact of low omega-3 diets on the differentiation of retinal layers and cholinergic markers in the retina. Female Lister Hooded rats and their litters were fed with either control (soy oil) or restricted (coconut oil) omega-3 diets. At various postnatal ages, rat pups received eye injections of neuronal tracers to visualize retinal axons at their brain targets. Lipid analysis indicated that the experimental diet led to a selective reduction in DHA content in the visual system. Omega-3 restriction induced an increase in the density of retinal axons in the superficial layers of the SC. This effect was observed throughout the stratum griseum superficiale (SGS), including the ventral and intermediate SGS layers at PND13, PND28 and PND42. The same pattern of expanded terminal fields was observed in the retinogeniculate pathways. The supplementation with fish oil (DHA) for two weeks was able to reverse the abnormal expansion of the retinocollicular projection. We also studied possible mechanisms involved in the loss of synaptic stabilization. Restricted omega-3 groups showed, in the visual layers of the SC decreased levels of GAP-43 phosphorylated form (pGAP-43) consistent with a reduction in synaptic stabilization. Omega-3 restriction increased the content of AMPAR subunits (GluR1 and GluR2) and decreased NMDAR (NR1, NR2A and NR2B) subunits. Omega-3 restricted groups showed a decrease in RXR?ї content and CREB phosphorylation (pCREB) in the visual layers of the superior colliculus. Retinal differentiation was

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: A low-tryptophan diet modulates spreading depression in the rat cortex.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims: The pharmacological treatment of rats with serotoninergic drugs clearly suggests an antagonistic role for the serotoninergic activity against the propagation of the excitability-related phenomenon known as cortical spreading depression (CSD). Here we investigated the possible action of a low-tryptophan diet on CSD propagation in the rat cortex.

Methods: Male Wistar rats received a 22% protein, low-tryptophan (0.05%) diet during gestation+lactation (group G+L; n=8), or during only lactation (group L; n=12), or at adulthood (group Ad; n=11). The dietary protein was from corn plus gelatin, which were very poor in tryptophan. Control groups (10 GL, 16 L and 6 Ad rats) received the same diet that was supplemented with 1% tryptophan. CSD was elicited in the frontal cortex at 20 min intervals by a 1-min application of a cotton ball (1-2 mm diameter) soaked with 2% KCl solution. We calculated the CSD velocity of propagation from the time required for a CSD wave to pass the distance between the two cortical electrodes. Data were analyzed by ANOVA, followed by a post-hoc test (Holm-Sidak). P values of less than 0.05 were considered significant.
Results: Compared with the respective controls, the tryptophan-deficient groups displayed higher (p < 0.01) CSD velocities. In the rats treated during lactation, the CSD acceleration was observed both just after weaning (recording at 30 days of life) and later in adulthood (recordings at 90 days of life). The mean (± standard deviation) CSD velocities for the low-tryptophan versus tryptophan-supplemented controls were (in mm/min): for the G+L groups, 3.85±0.27 versus 3.19±0.16; for the L groups, 3.75±0.20 versus 3.28±0.11 at 30 days of life, and 3.61±0.17 versus 3.18±0.08 at 90 days; for the Ad groups, 3.68±0.19 versus 3.21±0.11.
Conclusions: Data demonstrate that dietary tryptophan deficiency is associated with higher CSD propagation velocities. Considering that tryptophan is the precursor of serotonin synthesis, we suggest

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Effects of brain topical application of tibolone on the cortical spreading depression in castrated and non-castrated male rats.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Aims:
Sex steroid hormones can modulate cortical excitability, with an important repercussion on brain electrophysiological properties. Tibolone (TIB), a synthetic steroid, has been proposed as a neuroendocrine- and neurotransmitter modulator, exerting neuroprotective effects in in vivo and in vitro injury models. On the other hand, experimental evidence points to a role for the castration of male rats in neuronal activity and excitability. TIB can also increase free testosterone levels. However, it is unknown if castration modulates such TIB effect in males. Here we addressed this issue by characterizing the brain ability to propagate the phenomenon designated as Cortical Spreading Depression (CSD) in castrated and non-castrated male adult rats. CSD has been used as a physiological index to analyze the effects of topical TIB on the cerebral cortex.
Methods:
Wistar male adult rats (2-3 months old) were surgically castrated (n=8). After seven days, they were subjected to a 6-7 h CSD recording session, during which TIB (10 mg/ml) was topically applied, in a sequential manner, over two circular cortical regions (3?4 mm diameter) on the intact dura-mater. This castrated group was compared with a naпve (non-castrated) control group (n=10). The CSD propagation was evaluated before and after TIB application.
Results: 
After TIB application on the recording point 1, the basal CSD velocities (3.04±0.17 mm/min and 3.33±0.16 mm/min for castrated and naпve groups, respectively), fell to 2.75±0.26 mm/min and 2.86±0.19 mm/min, respectively (P<0.001). After the TIB effect was documented, the treated region was dried with cotton and subsequent CSD episodes confirmed the return of SD velocity to the basal levels (3.40±0.36 mm/min and 3.44±0.26 mm/min). Thereafter, a second application of TIB on the recording point 2 reduced the CSD velocities in the castrated and naпve groups to 2.79±0.32 mm/min and 3.00±0.24 mm/min, respectively, and the removal of TIB was followed by returnin

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: The potentiation of ECoG after spreading depression is modulated in adult rats by anesthetic agents, and by unfavorable lactation.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 9th World Congress, International Brain Research Organization

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
Cortical spreading depression (CSD) is characterized by reversible reduction of the evoked and spontaneous electrical activity in the cerebral cortex. Experimental evidence has suggested that CSD can modulate neural excitability and synaptic activity, with possible implications for the long-term potentiation. Systemic factors like anesthetic agents and hypoglycemia may influence CSD propagation, as well as the lactation conditions of the animal. We investigated the influence of two types of anesthetic agents (urethane + alpha-chloralose or tribromoethanol) on the possible effects of CSD in enhancing the electrocorticographic activity (ECoG) in adult male Wistar rats that were previously suckled in favorable and unfavorable conditions of lactation. Additionally, we observed whether this potentiation effect may be modulated by insulin-induced hypoglycemia. The rats were previously suckled in litters formed by 6 or 12 pups (termed L6 and L12 groups; respectively favorable and unfavorable lactation condition). In adulthood, we evaluate the increase in amplitude of electrocorticogram after the cortical tissue had been exposed to CSD in two cortical points with the support of an algorithm implemented in Matlab ? software. In the L12 condition, the rats presented significantly lower body- and brain weights than L6 control rats. Our data suggest that anesthetic agents and lactation condition modulate the potentiation induced by CSD on the amplitude of the ECoG and that insulin-induced hypoglycemia does not modify the anesthetic agents? effect. We also confirmed the regional cortical difference in potentiation of ECoG in anesthetized animals. Further studies shall deeply investigate the relevance of these findings for certain neurological diseases related to brain excitability, such as epilepsy.
